data.title: List of chemical element name etymologies
data.text:
Etymology of the chemical element names Element Original word Language of origin Meaning Nature of origin Name

(symbol) Z Description (symbol etymology, former names) Hydrogen (H) 1 á½•Î´Ï‰Ï (root: á½‘Î´Ï-) + Î³ÎµÎ½Î®Ï‚ (hydor genes) Greek via Latin and French "water + begetter" descriptive From French hydrogÃ¨ne[2] and Latin hydro- and -genes, derived from the Greek á½•Î´Ï‰Ï Î³ÎµÎ¯Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (hydor geinomai), meaning "Î™ beget water". Helium (He) 2 á¼¥Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚ (hÃ©lios) Greek "sun" astrological;

mythological Named after the Greek á¼¥Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚ (helios), meaning "the sun" or the mythological sun-god.[3] It was first identified by its characteristic emission lines in the Sun's spectrum. Lithium (Li) 3 Î»Î¯Î¸Î¿Ï‚ (lithos) Greek "stone" From Greek Î»Î¯Î¸Î¿Ï‚ (lithos) meaning "stone", because it was discovered from a mineral while other common alkali metals (sodium and potassium) were discovered from plant tissue. Beryllium (Be) 4 ?City of Belur via Greek Î²Î®ÏÏ…Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ (beryllos) Sanskrit, Pali, and Prakrit via Greek, Latin, Old French, and Middle English ?"beryl", a mineral descriptive (colour) Î²Î®ÏÏ…Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ (beryllos), denoting beryl, which contains beryllium.[4] The word is derived (via Latin: beryllus and French: bÃ©ryl) from the Greek Î²Î®ÏÏ…Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ (bÄ“rullos), "a blue-green spar", from Prakrit à¤µà¥†à¤°à¥à¤²à¤¿à¤¯â€Œ (veruliya), from PÄli à¤µà¥‡à¤²à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯ (veá¸·uriya), à¤­à¥‡à¤²à¤¿à¤°à¥ (veá¸·iru) or à¤­à¤¿à¤²à¤°à¥ (viá¸·ar): "to become pale", in reference to the pale semiprecious gemstone beryl.[5] Boron (B) 5 Ø¨ÙˆØ±Ù‚ (buraq) Arabic, Medieval Latin, Anglo-Norman, Middle French, and Middle English From the Arabic Ø¨ÙˆØ±Ù‚ (buraq), which refers to borax. Possibly derived from Persian Ø¨ÙˆØ±Ù‡ (burah). The Arabic was adapted as Medieval Latin baurach, Anglo-Norman boreis, and Middle English boras, which became the source of the English "boron". Carbon (C) 6 charbone Latin via French "charcoal" From French charbone, which in turn came from Latin carbÅ, meaning "charcoal" and is related to carbÅn, meaning "a coal". (The German and Dutch names, "Kohlenstoff" and "koolstof", respectively, both literally mean "coal matter".) These words come from the Proto-Indo-European base *ker- meaning "heat", "fire", or "to burn".[6] Nitrogen (N) 7 Î½Î¯Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ (Latin: nitrum) -Î³ÎµÎ½Î®Ï‚ (-genes) Greek via Latin and French "native-soda begetter" descriptive From French nitrogÃ¨ne[7] derived from Greek Î½Î¯Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ Î³ÎµÎ¯Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (nitron geinomai), meaning "I form/beget native-soda (niter)".[8] Â· Former name azote (French), from Greek á¼„Î¶Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (azÅtos) "lifeless" but possibly inspired by azoth, one of the alchemical names of mercury, from Andalusian Arabic al-zuq, the Classical Arabic name of that element. Oxygen (O) 8 á½€Î¾Ï Î³ÎµÎ¯Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (oxy geinomai)/oxygÃ¨ne Greek via French "to bring forth acid" From Greek á½€Î¾Ï Î³ÎµÎ¯Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ (oxy geinomai), meaning "Î™ bring forth acid", as it was believed to be an essential component of acids. This phrase was corrupted into the French oxygÃ¨ne, which became the source of the English "oxygen".[9] Fluorine (F) 9 fluor Latin "a flowing" From Latin fluor meaning "a flowing", from mineral name fluorspar (calcium fluoride). Fluorspar was used to make iron flowing in smelting. Neon (Ne) 10 Î½Î­Î¿Ï‚ (neos) Greek "new" From Greek Î½Î­Î¿Ï‚ (neos), meaning "new". Sodium (Na) 11 soda English From the English "soda", used in names for sodium compounds such as caustic soda, soda ash, and baking soda. Probably from Italian sida (or directly from Medieval Latin soda) meaning "a kind of saltwort", from which soda was obtained, of uncertain origin.[12] Â· Symbol Na is from the Neo-Latin noun natrium, derived from Greek Î½Î¯Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ (nÃ­tron), "natural soda, a kind of salt".[10] The original source is either the Arabic word Ù†Ø·Ø±ÙˆÙ† (natrun) or the Egyptian word netjeri.[11] Magnesium (Mg) 12 ÎœÎ±Î³Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¯Î± (Magnesia) Greek toponym From the Ancient Greek ÎœÎ±Î³Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¯Î± (Magnesia) (district in Thessaly), where it was discovered. Aluminium (Al) 13 alumen Latin "alum" (literally: bitter salt)[13] Latin alumen, which means "alum" (literally: bitter salt). Silicon (Si) 14 silex, silicis Latin "flint" descriptive From Latin silex or silicis, which means "flint", a kind of stone (chiefly silicon dioxide). Phosphorus (P) 15 Ï†á¿¶Ï‚ + Ï†ÏŒÏÎ¿Ï‚ (phos + phoros) Greek via Latin[14] "light-bearer" descriptive From Greek Ï†á¿¶Ï‚ + Ï†ÏŒÏÎ¿Ï‚ (phos + phoros), which means "light bearer", because white phosphorus emits a faint glow upon exposure to oxygen.

Phosphorus was the ancient name for Venus, or Hesperus, the Morning Star.[3] Sulfur (S) 16 Old Latin sulpur

(later sulphur, sulfur)

Proto-Indo-European *swÃ©plÌ¥

(genitive *sulplÃ³s),

nominal derivative of *swelp.[15] Latin

Proto-Indo-European (PIE) "to burn" The word came into Middle English from Anglo-Norman sulfre, itself derived through Old French soulfre from Late Latin sulfur.[16] From Proto-Indo-European *swelp "to burn" Chlorine (Cl) 17 Ï‡Î»Ï‰ÏÏŒÏ‚ (chlorÃ³s) Greek "pale green"[17] descriptive (colour) From Greek Ï‡Î»Ï‰ÏÏŒÏ‚ (chlorÃ³s), which means "yellowish green" or "greenish yellow", because of the colour of the gas. Argon (Ar) 18 á¼€ÏÎ³ÏŒÎ½ (argon) Greek "inactive" descriptive Greek argon means "inactive" (literally: "slow"). Potassium (K) 19 potassa; potasch via potash[18] Neo-Latin via Dutch and English[19] "pot-ash" From the English "potash": pot-ash (potassium compound prepared from an alkali extracted in a pot from the ash of burnt wood or tree leaves).

Potash is a calque of Dutch potaschen, which means "pot ashes".[19] Â· Symbol K is for the Latin name kalium, from Arabic Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ù„ÙŠ (al qalÄ«y), which means "calcined ashes". Calcium (Ca) 20 Ï‡Î¬Î»Î¹Î¾/calx Greek/Latin "pebble"/"limestone"[20] From Latin calx, which means "lime". Calcium was known as early as the first century when the Ancient Romans prepared lime as calcium oxide. Scandium (Sc) 21 Scandia Latin "Scandinavia" toponym Named from Latin Scandia, "Scandinavia". Â· Former name eka-boron[21] Titanium (Ti) 22 Î¤Î¹Ï„Î¬Î½, GEN: Î¤Î¹Ï„Î¬Î½Î¿Ï‚ (Titan) Greek "Titans", sons of Gaia mythological For the "Titans", the first offspring of Gaia in Greek mythology.[3] Vanadium (V) 23 VanadÃ­s Old Norse "DÃ­s of the Vanir" mythological From Old Norse VanadÃ­s, one of the names of the Vanr goddess Freyja in Norse mythology, because of multicoloured chemical compounds deemed beautiful.[3][22] Chromium (Cr) 24 Ï‡Ïá¿¶Î¼Î± (chrÃ³ma) Greek via French "colour" descriptive (colour) From Greek Ï‡Ïá¿¶Î¼Î± (chrÃ³ma), "colour", because of its multicoloured compounds. This word was adapted as the French chrome, and adding the suffix -ium created the English "chromium".[23] Manganese (Mn) 25 ÎœÎ±Î³Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¯Î±

(Magnesia;

Medieval Latin: magnesia) Greek via Latin, Italian, and French "Magnesia (regional unit)", Greece descriptive, toponym From Latin Magnesia, ultimately from Ancient Greek region Magnesia. The word Magnesia evolved into manganese in Italian and into manganÃ¨se in French. Iron (Fe) 26 Ä«sern

(earlier: Ä«ren/Ä«sen)

/yren/yron Old English via Middle English "holy metal or strong metal"[24] descriptive From the Anglo-Saxon Ä«sern which is derived from Proto-Germanic isarnan meaning "holy metal" or "strong metal". Â· Symbol Fe is from Latin ferrum, meaning "iron". Cobalt (Co) 27 Kobold German "goblin" From German Kobold, which means "goblin". The metal was named by miners, because it was poisonous and troublesome (polluted and degraded by other mined elements, such as nickel). Other sources cite the origin in the silver miners' belief that cobalt had been placed by "Kobolds", who had stolen the silver. Some suggest that the name may have been derived from Greek ÎºÏŒÎ²Î±Î»Î¿Ï‚ (kobalos), which means "mine" and which may have common roots with kobold, goblin, and cobalt. Nickel (Ni) 28 Kopparnickel/

Kupfernickel Swedish via German[25] "copper-coloured ore" descriptive From Swedish kopparnickel, meaning "copper-coloured ore". This referred to the ore niccolite from which it was obtained.[25] Copper (Cu) 29 ÎšÏÏ€ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ (Kyprios)? Greek? via Latin, West Germanic, Old English, and Middle English[26] "who/which is from Cyprus" toponym Possibly from Greek ÎšÏÏ€ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ (Kyprios) (which comes from ÎšÏÏ€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (Kypros), the Greek name of Cyprus) via Latin cuprum, West Germanic *kupar, Old English coper/copor, and Middle English coper. The Latin term, during the Roman Empire, was aes cyprium; aes was the generic term for copper alloys such as bronze. Cyprium means "Cyprus" or "which is from Cyprus", where so much of it was mined; it was simplified to cuprum and then eventually Anglicized as "copper" (Old English coper/copor). Â· Symbol Cu is from the Latin name cuprum ("copper"). Zinc (Zn) 30 Zink German ?"Cornet" From German Zink which is related to Zinken "prong, point", probably alluding to its spiky crystals. May be derived from Old Persian. Gallium (Ga) 31 Gallia Latin "Gaul" (Ancient France) toponym From Latin Gallia, which means "Gaul" (Ancient France), and also gallus, which means "rooster". The element was obtained as free metal by Lecoq de Boisbaudran, who named it after his native land France. Allegations were later made that he had also named it for himself, as gallus is Latin for le coq ("rooster"), but he denied that this had been his intention.[27] Â· Former name eka-aluminium by Mendeleev, who predicted its existence.[21] Germanium (Ge) 32 Germania Latin "Germany" toponym From Latin Germania, which means "Germany". Â· Former name eka-silicon by Mendeleev.[21] Arsenic (As) 33 á¼€ÏÏƒÎµÎ½Î¹ÎºÏŒÎ½ (arsenikon) Syriac/Persian via Greek, Latin, Old French, and Middle English ?"male" descriptive (colour) From Greek á¼€ÏÏƒÎµÎ½Î¹ÎºÏŒÎ½ (arsenikon), which is adapted from Syriac Ü Ü«Ü¢ÜÜ Ü Ü™ÜÜ¦Ü¢ÜÜâ€ ((al) zarniqa)[28] and Persian Ø²Ø±Ù†ÙŠØ® (zarnik), "yellow orpiment". The Greek arsenikon is paretymologically related to the Greek word á¼€ÏÏƒÎµÎ½Î¹ÎºÏŒÏ‚ (arsenikos), which means "masculine" or "potent". These words were adapted as the Latin arsenicum and Old French arsenic, which is the source for the English arsenic.[28] Selenium (Se) 34 ÏƒÎµÎ»Î®Î½Î· (selene) Greek "moon" astrological;

mythological From Greek ÏƒÎµÎ»Î®Î½Î· (selene), which means "Moon", and also moon-goddess Selene.[3] Bromine (Br) 35 Î²ÏÏŒÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ (brÃ³mos)[29] Greek via French "dirt" or "stench" (of male-goat)[30] Î²ÏÏŒÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ (brÃ³mos) means "stench" (literally: "clangor"), due to its characteristic smell. Krypton (Kr) 36 ÎºÏÏ…Ï€Ï„ÏŒÏ‚ (kryptos) Greek "hidden" descriptive From Greek ÎºÏÏ…Ï€Ï„ÏŒÏ‚ (kryptos), which means "hidden one", because of its colourless, odorless, tasteless, gaseous properties, as well as its rarity in nature. Rubidium (Rb) 37 rubidus Latin "deepest red" descriptive (colour) From Latin rubidus, which means "deepest red", because of the colour of a spectral line. Strontium (Sr) 38 Strontian Scottish Gaelic via English proper name toponym Named after strontianite, the mineral. Strontianite itself was named after the town of Strontian (Scotland) where the mineral was found; SrÃ²n an t-SÃ¬thein literally means "nose ['point'] of the fairy hill". Yttrium (Y) 39 Ytterby Swedish proper name toponym Named after the mineral yttria (yttriumoxide), where it was originally extracted from. Yttria itself was named after Ytterby, Sweden.[31] Zirconium (Zr) 40 Ü™ÜÜªÜ“Ü¥Ü¢Ü¥ (zargono),[32]

Ø²Ø±Ú¯ÙˆÙ† (zargÃ»n) Syriac/Persian via Arabic and German "gold-like" From Arabic Ø²Ø±ÙƒÙˆÙ† (zarkÃ»n). Derived from Persian Ø²Ø±Ú¯ÙˆÙ† (zargÃ»n), which means "gold-like". Zirkon is the German variant of these and is the origin of the English zircon.[33] Niobium (Nb) 41 ÎÎ¹ÏŒÎ²Î· (Niobe) Greek "snowy" mythological Named after Niobe, daughter of Tantalus in classical mythology.[22][3] Â· Former name columbium from Columbia, personification of America. Molybdenum (Mo) 42 Î¼ÏŒÎ»Ï…Î²Î´Î¿Ï‚ (molybdos) Greek "lead-like" descriptive From Greek Î¼ÏŒÎ»Ï…Î²Î´Î¿Ï‚ (molybdos), "lead", due to confusion with lead ore galena. Technetium (Tc) 43 Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î·Ï„ÏŒÏ‚ (technetos) Greek "artificial" descriptive From Greek Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î·Ï„ÏŒÏ‚ (technetos), which means "artificial", because it was the first artificially produced element. Â· Former name eka-manganese[21] Ruthenium (Ru) 44 Ruthenia Latin "Ruthenia", Kievan Rus'[34] toponym (exonym) From Latin Ruthenia, geographical exonym for Kievan Rus'. Rhodium (Rh) 45 á¿¥ÏŒÎ´Î¿Î½ (rhodon) Greek "rose" descriptive (colour) From Greek á¿¥ÏŒÎ´Î¿Î½ (rhodon), which means "rose". From its rose-red compounds. Palladium (Pd) 46 Î Î±Î»Î»Î¬Ï‚ (genitive: Î Î±Î»Î»Î¬Î´Î¿Ï‚) (Pallas) Greek via Latin "little maiden"[35] astrological;

mythological Named after Pallas, the asteroid discovered two years earlier. The asteroid itself was named after Pallas Athena, goddess of wisdom and victory.[3] The word Palladium is derived from Greek Î Î±Î»Î»Î¬Î´Î¹Î¿Î½ and is the neuter version of Î Î±Î»Î»Î¬Î´Î¹Î¿Ï‚, meaning "of Pallas".[36] Silver (Ag) 47 ğ’Š­ğ’ºğ’/ğ’Š­ğ’…ˆğ’‡¥ (siolfor/seolfor) Akkadian via Old English and Middle English "to refine", "smelt" Possibly borrowed from Akkadian ğ’Š­ğ’…ˆğ’‡¥ (sarpu) "refined silver" and related to ğ’Š­ğ’ºğ’ (sarapu) "to refine", "smelt".[37]

From Old English, seolfor which was derived from Proto-Germanic *silubra-; compare Old High German silabar; and has cognates in Balto-Slavic languages: sÄ­rebro, sidabras, Old Prussian sirablan.

Alternatively, possibly from one of the Pre-Indo-European languages, compare zilar. Â· Symbol Ag is from the Latin name argentum ("silver"), which is derived from Proto-Indo-European *arg-ent-. Cadmium (Cd) 48 ÎºÎ±Î´Î¼ÎµÎ¯Î± (kadmeia) Greek/Latin "Earth" (as classical element),

"calamine" or Cadmean earth[?] From Latin cadmia, which is derived from Greek ÎºÎ±Î´Î¼ÎµÎ¯Î± (kadmeia) and means "calamine", a cadmium-bearing mixture of minerals. Cadmium is named after Cadmus (in Greek: ÎšÎ¬Î´Î¼Î¿Ï‚: Kadmos), a character in Greek mythology and calamine is derived from Le Calamine, the French name of the Belgian town of Kelmis. Indium (In) 49 indigo Greek via Latin and English descriptive (colour) Named after indigo, because of an indigo-coloured spectrum line. The English word indigo is from Spanish indico and Dutch indigo (from Portuguese endego), from Latin indigo, from Greek á¼°Î½Î´Î¹ÎºÏŒÎ½ (indikon): "blue dye from India". Tin (Sn) 50 tin Anglo-Saxon via Middle English The word tin is borrowed from a Proto-Indo-European language, and has cognates in several Germanic and Celtic languages.[38] Â· Symbol Sn is from its Latin name stannum. Antimony (Sb) 51 Greek? via Medieval Latin and Middle English[41] various Possibly from Greek á¼€Î½Ï„Î¯ + Î¼ÏŒÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (anti + monos), approximately meaning "opposed to solitude", as believed never to exist in pure form, or á¼€Î½Ï„Î¯ + Î¼Î¿Î½Î±Ï‡ÏŒÏ‚ (anti + monachos) for "monk-killer" (in French folk etymology, anti-moine "monk's bane"), because many early alchemists were monks, and antimony is poisonous. This may also be derived from the Pharaonic (Ancient Egyptian), Antos Ammon (expression), which could be translated as "bloom of the god Ammo". Â· Symbol Sb is from Latin name stibium, which is derived from Greek Î£Ï„Î¯Î²Î¹ (stÃ­bi), a variant of ÏƒÏ„Î¯Î¼Î¼Î¹ (stimmi); genitive: ÏƒÏ„Î¯Î¼Î¼ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ or ÏƒÏ„Î¯Î¼Î¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï‚; probably a loan word from Arabic or Egyptian sdm meaning "eyepaint".[39][40] Tellurium (Te) 52 Tellus Latin "Earth" From Latin tellus, "Earth". Iodine (I) 53 á¼°ÏÎ´Î·Ï‚ (iodes) Greek via French "violet" descriptive (colour) Named after the Greek á¼°ÏÎ´Î·Ï‚ (iodes), which means "violet", because of the colour of the gaseous phase. This word was adapted as the French iode, which is the source of the English "iodine".[42] Xenon (Xe) 54 Î¾Î­Î½Î¿Ï‚ (xenos) Greek "foreign" From the Greek adjective Î¾Î­Î½Î¿Ï‚ (xenos): "foreign", "a stranger". Caesium (Cs) 55 caesius Latin "blue-gray"[43] or "sky blue" descriptive (colour) From Latin caesius, which means "sky blue". Its identification was based upon the bright-blue lines in its spectrum, and it was the first element discovered by spectrum analysis. Barium (Ba) 56 Î²Î±ÏÏÏ‚ (barys) Greek via Neo-Latin "heavy" Î²Î±ÏÏÏ‚ (barys) means "heavy". The oxide was initially called "barote", then "baryta", which was modified to "barium" to describe the metal. Humphry Davy gave the element this name because it was originally found in baryte, which shares the same source.[44] Lanthanum (La) 57 Î»Î±Î½Î¸Î¬Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ (lanthanein) Greek "to escape notice" From Greek Î»Î±Î½Î¸Î¬Î½Ï‰ (lanthÃ¡nÅ), "I escape notice". Cerium (Ce) 58 ceres Latin "grain", "bread" astrological;

mythological Named after the asteroid Ceres, discovered two years earlier. The asteroid itself, now classified as a dwarf planet, was named after Ceres, the goddess of fertility in Roman mythology.[3] Ceres is derived from Proto-Indo-European *ker-es- from base *ker- meaning "to grow".[45][46] Praseodymium (Pr) 59 Ï€ÏÎ¬ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¯Î´Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚ (prasios didymos) Greek "green twin" descriptive From Greek Ï€ÏÎ¬ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¯Î´Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚ (prasios didymos), meaning "green twin", because didymium[47] separates into praseodymium and neodymium. Neodymium (Nd) 60 Î½Î­Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¯Î´Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚ (neos didymos) Greek "new twin" descriptive From Greek Î½Î­Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î´ÏÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ (neos didymos), which means "new twin", because didymium[47] separated into praseodymium and neodymium. Promethium (Pm) 61 Î ÏÎ¿Î¼Î·Î¸ÎµÏÏ‚ (Prometheus) Greek "forethought"[48] mythological Named after Prometheus (a god in classical mythology), who stole the fire of heaven and gave it to mankind.[3] Samarium (Sm) 62 Samarsky-Bykhovets, Vassili eponym Named after the mineral samarskite, itself named after Colonel Vassili Samarsky-Bykhovets, a Russian mine official. Europium (Eu) 63 Î•á½ÏÏÏ€Î· (Europe) Ancient Greek "broad-faced" or "well-watered" toponym;

mythological Named for Europe, where it was discovered. Europe itself was named after Europa (consort of Zeus). Gadolinium (Gd) 64 Gadolin, Johan Finnish eponym Named in honour of Johan Gadolin,[49] who was one of the founders of Nordic chemistry research, and who discovered Â§ yttrium. The mineral gadolinite is also named after him. Terbium (Tb) 65 Ytterby Swedish proper name toponym Named after Ytterby, the village in Sweden where the element was first discovered.[31] Dysprosium (Dy) 66 Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ€ÏÏŒÏƒÎ¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (dysprositos) Greek "hard to get at" descriptive From Greek Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ€ÏÏŒÏƒÎ¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (dysprositos), which means "hard to get at". Holmium (Ho) 67 Holmia Latin "Stockholm" toponym From Latin Holmia, "Stockholm". Erbium (Er) 68 Ytterby Swedish proper name toponym Named after Ytterby, Sweden, where large concentrations of minerals yttria and erbia are located. Erbia and terbia were confused at this time. After 1860, what had been known as terbia was renamed erbia, and after 1877, what had been known as erbia was renamed terbia.[31] Thulium (Tm) 69 Î˜Î¿ÏÎ»Î· (ThoÃºlÄ“)[50] Greek "Thule" mythological Named after Thule, an ancient Roman and Greek name (Î˜Î¿ÏÎ»Î·) for a mythical country in the far north, perhaps Scandinavia. Ytterbium (Yb) 70 Ytterby Swedish proper name toponym Named after ytterbia, the oxide compound of ytterbium. Ytterbia itself was named after Ytterby, Sweden.[31][22] Lutetium (Lu) 71 Lutetia Latin "Paris" toponym Named after the Latin Lutetia (Gaulish for "place of mud"), the city of Paris.[22] Hafnium (Hf) 72 Hafnia Latin "Copenhagen" toponym From Latin Hafnia: "Copenhagen", Denmark. Tantalum (Ta) 73 Î¤Î¬Î½Ï„Î±Î»Î¿Ï‚ (Tantalus) Greek possibly "the bearer" or "the sufferer"[51] mythological Named after Greek Î¤Î¬Î½Ï„Î±Î»Î¿Ï‚ (Tantalus), who was punished after death by being condemned to stand knee-deep in water. If he bent to drink the water, it drained below the level he could reach (in Greek mythology). This was considered similar to tantalum's general non-reactivity (that is, "unreachability") because of its inertness (it sits among reagents and is unaffected by them).[3] Tungsten (W) 74 tung sten Swedish and Danish "heavy stone" descriptive From the Swedish and Danish "tung sten", which means "heavy stone". Â· Symbol W is from the German name Wolfram. Â· Former name Wolfrahm (German, literally "wolf cream") was the historical name. The names wolfram or volfram are still used in Swedish and several other languages.[22] Rhenium (Re) 75 Rhenus Latin "Rhine" toponym From Latin Rhenus, the river Rhine. Osmium (Os) 76 á½€ÏƒÎ¼Î® (osme) Greek via Neo-Latin "a smell" descriptive From Greek á½€ÏƒÎ¼Î® (osme), meaning "a smell", as osmium tetroxide is foul-smelling. Iridium (Ir) 77 á¼´ÏÎ¹Ï‚ (genitive: á¼´ÏÎ¹Î´Î¿Ï‚) (iris) Greek via Latin "of rainbows" descriptive (colour) Named after the Latin noun iris, which means "rainbow, iris plant, iris of the eye", because many of its salts are strongly coloured; Iris was originally the name of the goddess of rainbows and a messenger in Greek mythology.[3] Platinum (Pt) 78 platina (del Pinto) Spanish via Neo-Latin "little silver" (of the Pinto River)[52] descriptive From the Spanish, platina, which means "little silver", because it was first encountered in a silver mine. The modern Spanish is platino. Platina is a diminutive of plata (silver); it is a loan word from French plate or ProvenÃ§al plata (sheet of metal) and is the origin of the English "plate".[53] Gold (Au) 79 gold Old English via Middle English descriptive (colour) From the Old English "gold", from Proto-Indo-European *ghel- meaning "yellow/ bright". Â· Symbol Au is from Latin aurum, which means "shining dawn".[54] Mercury (Hg) 80 Mercurius Latin "Mercury", Roman god mythological Named after Mercury, the god of speed and messenger of the Gods, as was the planet Mercury named after the god. Â· Symbol Hg is from Latin hydrargyrum, which is from the Greek words á½•Î´Ï‰Ï and á¼€ÏÎ³Ï…ÏÏŒÏ‚ (hydor and argyros). Meaning "water-silver", because it is a liquid like water (at room temperature), and has a silvery metallic sheen.[3][55] Thallium (Tl) 81 Î¸Î±Î»Î»ÏŒÏ‚ (thallos) Greek "green twig" descriptive From Greek Î¸Î±Î»Î»ÏŒÏ‚ (thallos), which means "a green shoot (twig)", because of its bright-green spectral emission lines. Lead (Pb) 82 lead Anglo-Saxon Â· Symbol Pb is from the Latin name plumbum, still visible in the English plumbing.[3][56] Bismuth (Bi) 83 bisemutum Neo-Latin from German "white mass" descriptive (colour) bisemutum is derived from German Wismuth, perhaps from weiÃŸe Masse, and means "white mass", due to its appearance. Polonium (Po) 84 Polonia Latin "Poland" toponym Named after Poland, homeland of discoverer Marie Curie. Â· Former name radium F Astatine (At) 85 á¼„ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (astatos) Greek "unstable" From Greek á¼„ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (astatos), meaning "unstable". Â· Former name alabamine (Ab) was an earlier proposed name for astatine Radon (Rn) 86 radium Latin via German and English[57] Contraction of radium emanation, since the element appears in the radioactive decay of radium. Â· Former name niton (Nt), from Latin nitens "shining", because of the radioluminescence of radon. Francium (Fr) 87 France French toponym Named for France (literally: "Land of the Franks"), where it was discovered (at the Curie Institute, Paris). Radium (Ra) 88 radius Latin via French "ray" descriptive From Latin radius meaning "ray", because of its radioactivity. Americium (Am) 95 America toponym Named for the Americas, because it was discovered in the United States; by analogy with europium (Â§ Eu). The name of the continent America itself is derived from the name of the Italian navigator Amerigo Vespucci. Curium (Cm) 96 Curie, Marie and Pierre eponym Named in honour of Marie and Pierre Curie, who discovered radium and researched radioactivity. Berkelium (Bk) 97 University of California, Berkeley Anglo-Saxon via English toponym Named for the University of California, Berkeley, where it was discovered. The city of Berkeley itself was named after George Berkeley. Californium (Cf) 98 California English toponym Named for the state of California, US, and for University of California, Berkeley. The origin of the name California is disputed. Einsteinium (Es) 99 Einstein, Albert German eponym Named in honour of Albert Einstein, for his work on theoretical physics, which included the photoelectric effect. Fermium (Fm) 100 Fermi, Enrico Italian Italian surname eponym Named in honour of Enrico Fermi, who developed the first nuclear reactor, quantum mechanics, nuclear and particle physics, and statistical mechanics.
